"''...[t]o stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.''"

He then shattered her shield and broke her shield-arm with his mace, but was distracted by Merry, who stabbed him behind the knee with a [[Barrow-blade|sword enchanted with spells against him]]. Ãowyn seized the opportunity to strike the Witch-king with a killing blow "between crown and mantle". As her sword shattered, his clothing fell to the ground and he vanished with a wailing cry. In temperament she was idealistic, spirited, brave, high-minded, and lonely. ===Names and titles=== In the [[Old English language]] (the language Tolkien used to represent [[Rohirric]]) the word ''eoh'' (or ''eh'') means "war-horse, charger"[http://books.google.com/books?id=oXlii1KgDngC&printsec=frontcover&dq=eoh#PPA253,M1 Eoh: war-horse], Bosworth, Joseph, D.D., F.R.S. & Toller, T. Therefore, even though no such word appears in the lexicon of Old English, the name ''Ãowyn'' can be taken to mean "delightful charger".{{ME-ref|The Peoples of Middle-earth}}{{cite web|url=http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/mannish.htm|title=Various Mannish Tongues - the sadness of Mortal Men?|first=Helge|last=Fauskanger|publisher=''Ardalambion'' ([[Tolkien scholarship]])}} The first syllable of ''Ãowyn'' sounds like "eh-oh," with the "oh" just barely pronounced. Although she never carried the title of princess, she was a niece to one King of Rohan and sister to another, as well as the wife of a Gondorian prince. Ãowyn's titles included the '''(White) Lady of Rohan''', '''Lady of Ithilien''' and '''Lady of [[Emyn Arnen]]'''. Later he wrote: "Though not a 'dry nurse' in temper, she was also not really a soldier or 'Amazon', but like many brave women was capable of great military gallantry at a crisis."{{ME-ref|letters|#244}} (Here he alludes to Ãowyn's statement to Aragorn: "''But am I not of the House of Eorl, a shieldmaiden and not a dry-nurse?''") ==Portrayal in adaptations== [[Image:BakshiÃowyn.JPG|right|thumb|250px|Ãowyn, as portrayed in [[Ralph Bakshi]]'s ''[[The Lord of the Rings (1978 film)|The Lord of the Rings]]''.]] The voice of Ãowyn was provided by [[Nellie Bellflower]] in the 1980 [[Rankin/Bass]] animated version of ''[[The Return of the King (1980 film)|The Return of the King]]'', and by Elin Jenkins in [[BBC Radio]]'s 1981 [[The Lord of the Rings (1981 radio series)|serialisation]].
